reviewText: I chose to see "March of the Penguins" as a diversion to a 100+ degree day, and saw that cold weather is worse than hot weather.Penguins from several areas of Antarctica converge on land, safe from predators and the ebbing ice shelf. They are there to mate, birth, and care for their chick.Monogamous for that year, penguins pair up and the mother lays an egg.The mother dashes off back to the sea, which, thanks to the winter and new ice, is as far as 70 miles. She's starving, having lost one-third of her weight in laying the egg. The trip is long, and she's not fast. Hungry seals await them, some penguins lose their way, and some are too exhausted to continue.Well-fed, full of food for her chick, she returns, and the father makes the same trip so he can eat. The father stayed behind to incubate the egg, and protect the new chick. He has lost one half of his weight.The pair trade places a few more times as winter plods on. With temperatures 80 below zero, and winds up to 125, I felt cold just watching. The penguins huddle to keep warm, rotating which must do outside duty.Morgan Freeman narrates. His voice does not overcome the story. Better written than any documentary I have ever seen, Freeman respects the script. Having never seen a documentary in a theater before, I was impressed at how well it worked on the big screen.There is no plot, even though there is a beginning and an end. Unlike many documentaries, it does not detail the intricacies of eating, mate choosing, or science of penguin living. It is more about watching the arduous life cycle, with some explaining what we are watching.The camera works captures the cold -- the shivering penguins, the snow blowing like dust over the long line of marching penguins. It reminded me of movies about Siberia, showing Soviets living in a frozen, cold natural prison.This isn't a cute animal movie. Tender children might be saddened to see the eggs and chicks freezing, and could be quite frightened when the vicious seals overtake swimming penguins.I fully recommend "March of the Penguins."Anthony Trendleditor, HungarianBookstore.com

reviewText: March of the Penguins follows a year in the life of the male and female Emperor penguins.  After a summer of frolicking in the refreshing artic waters and building up body fat, they begin the long trek to their sheltered mating ground area 70 miles away.  Here, at what looks like a massive penguin cocktail party, the penguins pair off one by one, looking for all the world like they are head over heels in love.  Each of these unions produces a single egg, which the mother passes to the father to protect for the winter months while she returns to the ocean to feed, as giving birth has left her near starvation.Once the mothers leave, the fathers huddle together, enduring unimaginably hazardous conditions in order to ensure the safe hatching of their little chicks.  Eventually, the mothers return to meet and nourish their little ones, while the fathers--now near starvation themselves--take their own turn at feeding.  Amazingly, the fathers are able to learn the unique call of their newborns so that they will be able to find each other upon their return.  The father and mother continue to switch places until finally, the entire family is ready to make the journey back to the sea and the reluctant youngsters are ready to set forth on their own.Although I've seen many National Geographic and similar TV specials telling much the same story featured here, seeing this film's stunningly gorgeous photography on the wide screen definitely made the trip to the theater worth it.  Although I would recommend this as a family film, I would caution parents of young children, as the little ones might well be frightened by the treacherous snow storms as well as several penguin deaths (including the loss of a chick and the capture of an adult by a seal).  Overall, however, I highly recommend this feature, particularly to anyone who would like to witness the miracle life as evidenced by one very resilient species.

reviewText: In a place as inhospitable as the Antarctic, almost the entire planet will never know the treacherous nature of this continent during its long winter months. There are no land based mammals that could possibly survive here ...except for the Emperor Penguins. Why they still choose to nest here is a mystery (personally if I were them I'd be sucking down drinks poolside in Hawaii or something), but nest they do. And they come by their hundreds, leaping out of the chilly ocean and marching (in March) single-file to their favorite breeding spot, the exact same location where they were born years before. They must have an amazing internal compass.They hike over 70 miles, never eating or drinking, just so they can match up with the opposite sex and produce one egg. And if their egg survives the blistering 80-plus degree below zero temperatures, the shuffling from one parent's feet to another's, the bustling and jostling amongst hundreds of other penguins, they might have a fighting chance. But even if they do survive this, the chicks still have to evade predator birds, and other pitfalls that takes lives so easily in this nearly lifeless land.Narrated by Morgan Freeman's wonderful voice and filmed in unGodly cold conditions, this documentary deserves all the praise it has received.My only beef with the film is that, at times, it seemed to be too anthropomorphic, using words like "love", etc. to describe how the parents' cared for each other and their chicks. Whether this is true or not, we'll never know, but what it does do is get the viewer into these animals' lives very intimately (uh-oh! There I go, too!)This is a great, short film that the entire family can enjoy. And oogling a the cinematography on a big screen is a major bonus as well.

reviewText: How refreshing it is to see a real documentary do well at the box office as opposed to junk documentaries, reflecting the film maker's political biases, which have polluted the box office in recent years. Luc Jacquet's exquisitely filmed nature film promises to be the second largest grossing documentary in the history of the cinema. This compelling film shows the migration of Emperor Penguins as they march 70 miles, through harsh Antartic terrain and weather, to breed. It is extraordinary how they overcome the conditions to reach their goal. Once they reach the breeding grounds, they find mates and for that particular mating season, they remain monogamous.What is particularly compelling is the beautifully filmed social structure of the penguins. The camera catches them seemingly genuinely in love with their mates. When the eggs are laid, they must be shielded from the cold to survive and the mother transfers the egg to the father. It is then the father's job to keep the egg warm while the mother marches back, with the other mothers, to feed and bring back enough food for their soon to be hatched chicks. When they get back, they are able to find their husbands among the man hundreds of other penguins because they learn each other's voices. If a chick dies, the mother's genuine grief, so poignantly captured by the camera, is heart rending. Meanwhile, to survive the harsh winter storms, the penguins huddle together to keep warm and they take turns going into the middle of the group (where it is warmest) and to the outer edge of the group (where they are providing warmth for the others). Later, it becomes the fathers' turn to feed and bring back food for the chicks. Before leaving, they talk to the chicks so they can recognize each others' voices and find each other when they return. They leave and return as a group and somehow find one another in the cacaphony of penguin sounds. How truly extraordinary these creatures are!Morgan Freeman is the narrator and he does a superb job of telling the tale of these noble creatures. Meanwhile, in the closing credits, you see the film makers braving the same conditions the penguins do (after all, the movie didn't film itself. Human beings had to endure the 80 below temperatures and violent storms too). I enjoyed this film and it deserves the kudos that it has received. I highly recommend it.

reviewText: In a summer featuring mostly lackluster movies, Luc Jacquet's "March of the Penguins" has become a sleeper hit. Why are so many people flocking to a movie about Antarctic birds? Perhaps because it is absolutely fascinating to watch these incredible creatures overcome tremendous odds in order to mate and nurture their young."March of the Penguins" deals with the yearly ritual of thousands of Emperor penguins who live in Antarctica. They leave the sea, which is their source of food, and trek seventy miles to their breeding grounds. When they reach their destination, they mate, and if the mother conceives and later lays an egg, the father takes care of it in his body while the mother makes the long trip back to the sea to gather food. Months later, the chick hatches, and the mother returns with food for her baby. Then, the father travels to the sea to take his turn to feed. The mother protects and nourishes her chick until he is able to take care of himself. During the pitiless winter season, the blizzards and biting winds present a tremendous challenge. The penguins huddle together to keep from freezing, but not all of them survive. If they manage to avoid succumbing to the cold, some penguins fall prey to accidents or predators. Living through this punishing yearly cycle is nothing short of miraculous.This movie is a feast for the eyes. Cinematographers Laurent Chalet and Jérme Maison capture the forbidding and desolate beauty of Antarctica. The panoramic view of hundreds of penguins waddling down the ice in formation, and occasionally sledding on their bellies, is awesome. I also loved the intimate shots of the penguins, featuring close-ups of their piercing eyes, clawed feet, and furry skin. The director skillfully engages the audience's emotions; we root for the penguins to stay warm, obtain food, and live to produce a new generation. Composer Alex Wurman's lovely original score complements the film perfectly. Morgan Freeman, with his sonorous voice and superb diction, provides the moving and occasionally humorous narration.Some scientists criticize the filmmakers' implication that penguins can love and mourn, much as people do. Ascribing human characteristics to birds may be scientifically invalid, but it does make the audience connect with the penguins in a very personal way. "March of the Penguins" is a moving, poignant, and unforgettable film, and I predict that it will become a classic among nature documentaries.

reviewText: It is comforting to know that every once in a while, moviegoers can surprise you.  Finally showing their weariness for in-your-face explosion-happy summer blockbusters, the public is flocking (bad pun, sorry) to Luc Jacquet's charming natural history documentary "March of the Penguins".Ironically, the most interesting thing about this film is that it is an entirely ordinary nature documentary, backed by the National Geographic Society.  It is interesting because the masses have somehow connected with it.There are no characters, no dialogue, and no special effects.  It is an informative film about the nurturing habits of Antarctica's Emperor Penguins, narrated by Morgan Freeman.  It should be noted that Morgan Freeman serves as a narrator for another, very different film currently occupying the multiplexes:  "War of the Worlds".For a bird living in the coldest place on Earth, who spends most of its time bracing against the biting wind (in a head-down stance, as if they all lost their contact lenses) "March of the Penguins" makes their lives emotional and enthralling.Rather than following a particular penguin, or having an actual plot, like "The Bear", this film plays like any other documentary you would see on the Discovery Channel or Animal Planet, staying objective, but allowing the audience to become attached to the adorable birds anyway.Life in Antarctica is tough, however, and, as my calculus-teacher cousin is fond of saying, "the real world is not nice."  Not all of the penguins can survive the brutal winter or voracious predators, but death is dealt with so poetically that even the little ones won't be made too upset.However, they may become a little bored, as the film isn't quite the roller coaster of eye candy they've gotten used to over the past few months.  Some parts, like some parts of life, are slow, with not a whole lot going on.  This movie has been called things like "the best family film of the year", but despite it's rather short running time, the kids may be a bit squirmy or even sleepy if they're too young.The music won't help matters; it is that sort of "New Age" soothing and calm stuff, and you may have to poke your neighbor if it puts him to sleep."March of the Penguins" doesn't overly anthropomorphize these animals, like Jean-Jacques Arnaut's "The Bear" and "Two Brothers" do.  While it is clear these penguins have emotions such as grief, jealousy, and attachment in the film, it is also clear that this wasn't manufactured to make them more appealing to us.  They have real emotions and personalities, complex as any of ours.Nearly as refreshing as a dip in the pool on these scorching summer days, this film's beautiful vistas of ice and snow are welcome relief from the August heat.

reviewText: I have long been an admirer of penguins, so when this film was released in the cinema, my friends variously and collectively rushed to inform me of the film.  I went to see it, and was amazed.The plot of the film is extraordinarily simple - the film follows the Emperor Penguins of Antarctica during their annual mating and rearing cycle.  It is framed from start to finish in terms of the march - the march from the sea to the mating spot, the march to return to the sea for food, the march again for rearing the young, and the march again finally to return to the sea.There is a great deal of humour and grace; penguins are gentle beings, vulnerable to predators and to the hazards of the winter - despite being fashioned for some of the coldest climates on earth, they nonetheless require warmth, particularly for their eggs and the hatchlings.  In the severe cold and far-below-zero windchills, many do not make it, and the one negative side of the film for me was a somewhat constant lingering on this downside.  While it is a part of nature, it still becomes a bit more tragic in the cycle of the film than it needs to be.  As this is billed as a family film, I worried that some of the children viewing might be more emotionally upset at this than they needed to be.Still, the details presented are fascinating, and it is a true testament to filmmaking that these shots and images were captured as dramatically, humourously, gracefully and beautifully as they were.This film has 'Academy Award' written all over it, in many categories.  Cinematography, musical score, directing, documentary - these are only some of the categories in which this film is likely to get a nod.  Morgan Freeman never appears on camera, but gives a wonderful reading as the narrator of this visual feast, adding subtle emphasis that never detracts and often adds to the tale in the English-language version of this film.Director Luc Jacquet and cinematographers, Laurent Chalet and Jerome Maison have produced a masterpiece that transcends language barriers (indeed, there is no native human language for Antarctica).  A French team, they have translated this film into many languages around the world, as people everywhere will find something with which they can relate.Perhaps the most skillful part of the filming was to make Antarctica seem so varied in texture and place; on a continent covered with ice and snow, one still gets the sense of the length of the journey, the beauty inherent in the surroundings, and the dangers involved for the penguins.Be sure to stay for the credits, as one gets to see the film crew in some light-hearted scenes with curious penguins.

reviewText: "March of the Penguins" is delightfully photographed, visually compelling, and often emotionally engaging. It tells the story of the long waddling marches that Emperor Penguins undertake each year to reach their breeding grounds, to mate and to care for their young. Living at what seems like the absolute margins of conditions hospitable to life, these beautiful animals display a range of adaptations (plumage, care of the young, temporary monogamy) that are fascinating. It doesn't hurt that penguins are funny-looking, generally harmless and their chicks are adorable fuzzballs.Still, this is a hard movie to rate. If you're a little kid (5-10) or an adult with no particularly interest in the science of animal behavior, you will adore it. Others will find less than in the movie than meets the eye. The title for this review comes from my 16-year-old, who (like me and the rest of the family) found the film beautiful to watch but leaving us with nothing to talk about afterwards.The rest of the review catalogs some of the movie's failings, so stop here if you are a diehard fan!"March of the Penguins" is a perfect movie for the current American anti-scientific and hyper-moral climate. It's a movie with practically no sex, no mention of the E-word (evolution) but preaching pro-family values -- that is, if you are a primate, specifically a human one. You will see funny shots of penguins slipping on ice and sliding on their bellies, but never learn how long they live. You will see the death of an egg or two but never learn how many eggs are lost to freezing, inept parents, theft or predation. You will see penguin couples seem to cuddle with their monogamous partners, but have no insight into the nature of their bond. You will see mothers "grieving" for their young, but not learn to what degree penguins are capable of emotions, at least in the human sense of the word. And you will certainly not be challenged to consider the degree to which *human* emotions are based in biology rather than morality. Speaking of morality, the movie, subtitled "Love Finds a Way" is practically a faunal sermon on the virtues of heterosexual monogamy. One wonders how much film was expended in the effort to depict penguins appearing to fulfill human ideals.Still, the film is worth seeing, if only to witness the grand excesses to which earthly life will go in order to propagate itself. And it's not often that we can witness 9 straight months of life in the Antarctic. Morgan Freeman's sonorous narration is suitably grave for the subject. The musical accompaniment is often moving, and only occasionally overblown, as with the accompaniment to the very brief scene of penguins mating. The score at this point was so vibrantly and earnestly ethereal that it seemed penguin sex was the apotheosis of human experience."March of the Penguins" is not a movie you will regret viewing, but it may well leave you hoping that "Animal Planet" gives the Emperor Penguin a more thorough treatment.

reviewText: A couple of years back, filmgoers were offered the magnificent and exquisitely photographed WINGED MIGRATION. Don't go to MARCH OF THE PENGUINS expecting something comparable.Narrated by one of the most recognizable voices in the movie industry, Morgan Freeman, this documentary by National Geographic Feature Films follows a year in the life of Emperor penguins in the Antarctic. The story begins in March, the Southern Hemisphere's Fall season, when the birds leave the sea and take to the ice, trudging (up to) seventy miles to their ancestral breeding grounds. There, males and females pair off into monogamous couples. After the female produces a single egg, she leaves it in the custody of the male while she treks back to the sea where she'll feed during the worst of the winter, getting enough food to take back to her young chick, which hatches as the sun again peeps over the horizon after days of total darkness. Once having returned, the mother takes up guardianship of the hatchling while the father, now having gone without food for several months, makes the arduous journey back to the ocean for groceries. This cycle repeats until November, when the melting of ice flows brings the shoreline closer to the breeding grounds. Eventually, in the Antarctic summer, adults and their offspring all return to the water.Whereas WINGED MIGRATION followed several bird species over intercontinental distances to and from varied and exotic locales, MARCH OF THE PENGUINS is necessarily narrower in scope. And most of the latter film takes place on the ground; there aren't the stunning visuals of birds in flight as in the former. In any case, MARCH didn't elicit from me any soto voce exclamations of "Wow!" or "Way cool!". However, as the film did (perhaps) excessively anthropomorphize the feelings of the penguin mates to each other and their attachment to the egg and subsequent chick, especially as verbally described by the dulcet Freeman, there were several outburst of "Awwwwwww" from other members of the audience.I don't wish to denigrate the achievement of the French production team, headed by director Luc Jacquet, in creating this fine documentary under (presumably) harsh conditions. It's only in the end credits that we see brief snippets of the film crew on location with their cameras. (For all I know, they could've been working out of a heated Quonset hut with all the amenities just out of camera frame.) Indeed, the underwater and under-ice sequences of hunting and feeding penguins are perhaps the most impressive on the reel. They've created a film for the whole family to enjoy, a fact not lost on the studios or theater management, which front loaded MARCH with trailers for five kids-oriented films - four animated features and one Disney flick.I'm awarding four stars only relative to WINGED MIGRATION, a more exceptional cinematic accomplishment by far and one without the warm and fuzzy overtones. reviewText: In the harshest environment in the world, Antarctica, an amazing gathering accumulates once a year in the name of love. Through the opportunity to observe these penguins a notion rises that the penguins must coexists with nature in a delicate balance where life and death weigh equal. Yet, it is within the illogical reasoning out of a humans point of view that mankind must realize its powerful position in the global ecosystem.  Humans have over an extended time continued to destroy nature in a progressive manner through exploitation, toxic waste disposal, and other natural disasters created by man, which many parts of the human society still deny.  The aftermath could change the environmental balance for the penguins, and only a slight change could have a disastrous effect on the existence of the Emperor penguin.  The film does not deal directly with mankind's influence on nature, but the notion lingers throughout the film.Once the penguins reached the location of mating it is hard to believe that love can take place in such a place where natural selection and death are as common as snow. One prolonged scene, displays the repercussion of careless penguin couple, as the egg slowly breaks from the freezing temperatures. reviewText: The ad campaign for Luc Jacquet's brilliant "March of the Penguins" is slightly misleading, as is its "G" rating. This film by rights should be "PG," because the scenes of penguins beset by fierce Antarctic storms and even fiercer predators would be extremely upsetting to very small children. Like the death of Bambi's mother and the donkey-boys in "Pinocchio," the sight of baby penguins chased by hungry gooney birds will create untold numbers of screaming nightmares for generations of three- and four-year-olds. "March of the Penguins" is a family film only for families whose children are old enough to understand that the course of nature includes tragedy and death. That said, it's an awe-inspiring, uniquely moving and uplifting film, full of "How did they film that?" cinematic moments and bolstered by a haunting music score. By showing us the incredible hardships that emperor penguins endure in order to survive and propagate, Jacquet reclaims for us a little-known phenomenon of the natural world, and fills us with admiration and love for some of the noblest, bravest, most endearing creatures on God's earth. Jacquet wisely avoids trying to personalize the penguins, a' la Disney documentaries, but Morgan Freeman's narration can't help ascribing human emotions of courage, sorrow and joy to the penguins (and, indeed, forgoing such anthromorphization would have taken superhuman effort, considering what the penguins go through). Be sure to stay for the final credits, which show the hardships that Jacquet and his crew endured, as well as charming scenes of the human filmmakers interacting with the ever-curious penguins. But be warned: if you take your younger children to see this film, be prepared to invest in a night light, and to spend the wee hours comforting sons and daughters who just dreamed a seal was about to eat them.

reviewText: This movie is pretty much review-proof, in my opinion.  What can you criticize?  The way the story turns out?  How the penguins look?  What they do? Part of their behavior, as far as traveling to the same place inland year after year, has been hardwired into them.  But you have to wonder if when this all first started, the place they trekked to wasn't closer to the ocean (where they go for food).  Antarctica is constantly changing.  Couldn't the penguins find a new place to seek some modest shelter?  In some ways, they are like Salmon swimming upstream to spawn and die at the place they were born.  If that darn salmon just wasn't so insistent on going to the EXACT spot...it would be much more likely to spawn AND survive to spawn another year.Anyway, the other amazing part of the film is the work of the documentary crew. reviewText: There used to be a time when at least one nature documentary was released on a massive national scale about every other year. Disney used to be the major Hollywood producer and distributor of these films because they were so family friendly, but there were other studios and independent agencies involved, too. Around the late 1970s, these movies virtually stopped being released. Perhaps it was because of STAR WARS (that film changed everything else in the business, why not nature documentaries, too). Perhaps it was because people just didn't care about animals anymore. Whatever the reasons, major nature documentaries released on a large scale haven't been seen in most theatres around the country for a long time.Until the summer of 2005. That's when MARCH OF THE PENGUINS became the little picture that could and went on to become the highest-grossing documentary of all time (I don't care how they classify it , FAHRENHEIT 9/11 is not a documentary).MARCH OF THE PENGUINS illustrates a nine-month cycle in the life of Emperor Penguins. Each year these birds trek to the same breeding grounds in Antarctica, battling sub-zero temperatures, bone-chilling winds, and ferocious predators all in the name of love and survival. The Emperor Penguin mating rites are one of love because these penguins remain monogamous to their spouses throughout the mating season, they only separate after it's time to leave their little ones behind.MARCH OF THE PENGUINS is a beautifully filmed picture. It not only captures the beauty of nature, but illustrates its wrath as well. Baby penguins are born, but in the process old penguins die and others are eaten by sea lions. It's a difficult lesson for children to grasp, but it is presented so well in the movie that it teaches children about the survival of a species, but without worrying them unduly.Morgan Freeman narrates the picture and his soulful voice adds a distinct flair. As a piece of trivia, Freeman recorded all of his narration in a single day.I'm a huge fan of penguins and if I had the money and resources, I would own a frozen penguin refuge somewhere. I figured since I couldn't do that the next best thing I could do was to see MARCH OF THE PENGUINS. I absolutely loved it and can't wait to see it again.

reviewText: Though they are my favorite animals, I did not expect penguins to be as expressive as they are in this film; in fact, their emotions are made so palpable you feel as if you are watching people interact as they march across some barren continent. That is this popular documentary's greatest achievement: making one realize the humanity in the creatures some claim have no feelings. Jacqet contradicts such statements with masterfully observed sequences such as a male and female penguin exploring each other's bodies lovingly, almost like youthful teenagers experiencing sex for the first time in some nostalgic summer romance. Additionally, Jacquet skillfully forms a bond between audience and subject through the long (but entertaining) marching process. For instance, when baby penguins die and mothers are left alone, their cries of agony hit with an unexpected punch: seeing these penguins make such a difficult journey only to lose the entire purpose of leaving home becomes absolutely devastating. Fortunately, the film is full of humor and is aesthetically pleasing, with stellar camera work that portrays Antarctica as a series of monoliths reminiscent of human faces, a snowed-over version of what we imagine Mars to be. Ultimately, Jacquet achieves success in not allowing boredom to be among the myriad emotions one feels throughout the documentary; "March of the Penguins" is obviously one of the most complete films of the year, distinguished in how compelling a literal march of penguins becomes through the eyes of someone as curious about penguins as Jacquet.
